revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Shams ud-Din Tabriz 1502-1504 BNF Paris.jpg|right|thumb|210px|A page of a copy circa 1503 of the ''Dīvān-e Šams-e Tabrīzī'']] {{Sufism}} '''''Dīvān-e Kabīr''''' or '''''Dīvān-e Šams-e Tabrīzī''''' ''(The Works of [[Shams Tabrizi|Šams Tabrīzī]])'' ({{Lang-fa|دیوان شمس تبریزی}}) or '''''Dīvān-e Šams''''' is one of [[Mawlānā Jalāl-ad-Dīn Muhammad Balkhī]]'s masterpieces. A collection of lyric poems that contains more than 40,000 verses, it is written in the [[New Persian]] language and is considered one of the greatest works of [[Persian literature]]. ''Dīvān-e Kabīr'' ("the great divan") contains poems in several different styles of Eastern-Islamic poetry (e.g. odes, eulogies, quatrains, etc.). It contains 44,282 lines (according to Foruzanfar's edition,Furuzanfar, Badi-uz-zaman. ''Kulliyat-e Shams'', 8 vols., Tehran: Amir Kabir Press, 1957–66. Critical edition of the collected odes, qutrains and other poems of Rumi with glossary and notes. which is based on the oldest manuscripts available): 3,229 odes, or ghazals (total lines = 34,662); 44 tarji-bands (total lines = 1698); and 1,983 quatrains (total lines = 7932).{{cite web|url=http://www.dar-al-masnavi.org/about_divan.html|title=About the Divan|work=dar-al-masnavi.org|accessdate=24 December 2016}} Although most of the poems are in [[New Persian]], there are also some in [[Arabic language|Arabic]], and a small number of mixed Persian/Greek and Persian/Turkish poems. ''Dīvān-e Šams-e Tabrīzī'' is named in honour of Rumi's spiritual teacher and friend [[Shams Tabrizi]]. == Greco-persian and Greek poems == The following poem of Rumi is written in persian while the last words of each verse end with a Greek word{{Cite news|url=http://parsianjoman.org/?p=6002|title=واژه‌های یونانی در غزل‌های مولانا|date=۱۳۹۷-۱-۱۹ ۲۱:۱۷:۳۰ +۰۰:۰۰|work=پارسی‌انجمن|access-date=2018-11-12|language=fa-IR}}; # ''<<νηστικός /نیم شب از عشق تا دانی چه می‌گوید خروس: <<خیز شب را زنده دار و روز روشن نستکوس '' # ''άνεμος/پرها بر هم زند یعنی دریغا خواجه‌ام : روزگار نازنین را می‌دهد بر آنموس '' # '' άνθρωπος/ در خروش است آن خروس و تو همی در خواب خوش : نام او را طیر خوانی نام خود را آنثروپوس'' # '' άγγελος/ آن خروسی که تو را دعوت کند سوی خدا: او به صورت مرغ باشد در حقیقات انگلوس'' # ''βασιλιάς/ من غلام آن خروس ام که او چنین پندی دهد : خاک پای او بِ آید از سر واسیلیوس'' # ''καλόγερος/ گَردِ کفشِ خاکِ پای مصطفی را سرمه ساز : تا نباشی روز حشر از جمله‌ی کالویروس'' # ''Σαρακηνός/رو شریعت را گزین و امر حق را پاس دار : گر عرب باشی و اگر ترک و اگر سراکنوس'' The following are Greek verses in the poetry of [[Rumi|Mawlana Jalal ad-Din Rumi]] (1207-1273), and his son, [[Sultan Walad]] (1226-1312). The works have been difficult to edit, because of the absence of vowel pointing in most of the verses, and the confusion of scribes unfamiliar with Greek; different editions of the verses vary greatly{{Cite web|url=http://www.opoudjis.net/Play/rumiwalad.html|title=Untitled Document|website=www.opoudjis.net|access-date=2018-11-12}}: {| class="wikitable" |+Greek verses in the poetry of Rumi !Verse !Greek Phrases (written in the persian script by Rumi) !Greek equivalent !Persian Translation !English Translation |- |1a |افندیس مَس ان، کی آگاپومن تُن/دُن |Αφέντης μας έν κι αγαπούμεν τον |او سرور ما است و ما او را دوست داریم) عاشق او ایم) |He is our Master and we love him |- |1b |کی اپ اکِینون اِن کالی زوی مَس |κι απ’ εκείνον έν καλή η ζωή μας |به خاطر او است که زندگی ما خوش است |It is because of him that life is sweet |- |2a |ییَتی ییریسِس، ییَتی ورومیسِس |γιατί γύρισες γιατί βρώμισες |چرا برگشتی؟ چرا بیمار ای؟ |Why did you turn around because you were ill? |- |2b |په مه تی اپاتِس، په مه تی اخاسِس |πε με τι έπαθες, πε με τι έχασες! |به من بگو ترا چه افتاد؟ به من بگو چه گم کرده‌ای؟ |Tell me what happend to you? Tell me what did you loose? |- |11a |ایلا کالی مو! ایلا شاهی مو! |Έλα καλέ μου, έλα σάχη μου· |بیا زیبای من. بیا شاه من |Come my beautiful, come my king. |- |11b |ایلا کالی مو! ایلا شاهی مو! |χαρά δε δίδεις, δος μας άνεμο! |[اگر] شادی نمی‌دهی، به ما رایحه‌ای بده. |If you do not give us joy, give us "wind"/"breath"! |- |12a |پو دیپسا پینِی، پو پونِی لَلِی |Που διψά πίνει, που πονεί λαλεί· |آن که تشنه است می‌نوشد، آن که خسته [=زخمی] است می‌گرید |The thirsty one drinks while the wounded one flees |- |12b |میدِن چاکوسِس، کاله، تو ییالی |μηδέν τσάκωσες, καλέ, το γυαλί |ای زیبا، آیا تو جام را شکسته‌ای؟ |Tell me beautiful, did you break the cup? |} [[File:Turkey.Konya019.jpg|thumb|left|225px|
Dīvān-e Kabīr (''Divan-ı Kebir'') from 1366
Mevlâna mausoleum, Konya, Turkey
]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Rumi}} {{Persian literature}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Divan-E Shams-E Tabrizi}} [[Category:13th-century books]] [[Category:Works by Rumi]] [[Category:Persian literature]] [[Category:Sufi literature]] [[Category:Persian books]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/189.143.7.247|189.143.7.247]] identified as test/vandalism.
revision.text:
'''[[Quebec]]''' has a rich history of [[folklore]], second only to that of the indigenous peoples.
==Folk tales== Folktales were told by ''Raconteurs'', who could tell tales lasting several hours, or even tell a story over the course of several evenings.<ref>{{cite book |title=Canadian Folk-Life and Folk-Lore |last= Greenough |first=William P. |year=1897 |publisher= George H. Richmond| location= New York, NY.}}</ref> Christian beliefs and [[superstitions]] are present in most Quebec folklore. La [[chasse-galerie]] (the flying canoe) is a well-known folktale about a group of lumberjacks who make a pact with the devil. Demons, witches, and werewolves were common folk motifs.<ref>{{cite book|last=Haase|first=Donald|title=The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Folktales and Fairy Tales: A-F|date=2008|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780313334429|page=378}}</ref> The tales themselves were referred to by the name ''contes''. The traditional ''conte'' form of story-telling has been adapted to the modern novel by writers such as [[Roch Carrier]] and [[Joseph Jean Jacques Ferron]].<ref>{{cite book|last=New|first=William H.|title=Encyclopedia of Literature in Canada|date=2002|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=9780802007612|pages=354–5}}</ref> Some folktales are classified under the traditional genre ''Märchen'' ([[fairy tale]]s).
''The Devil at the Dance'' is an example in which the Devil was used to reinforce Christian ideals. It is the story of a young couple in love. The girl's parents, who are [[Heretics]], refuse the young man as a suitor after discovering he is Christian. When the daughter protests, her mother announces that she would rather have the Devil himself courting her daughter than the young Christian. The following Sunday afternoon, a stranger comes to call: the Devil himself. The three of them-mother, father and daughter-are converted by a priest, and the young couple are then married.<ref name="Chiasson">{{cite book |title=Les Légendes des îles de la Madeleine |last= Chiasson |first=Père Anselme |year=1969 |publisher= Éditions des Aboiteaux |location= Moncton, N.-B.}}</ref>
There are various versions of this tale: One paints the young girl as being very disobedient and flirtatious. Although her parents warn her of the evils of selfishness, her actions do not change. Thus, the Devil was able to enter her home because of her Unchristian behavior. She is saved once again by the Priest, and converts to Christianity. Another version has the tale happening in a remote village in [[New Brunswick]], but with the same basic storyline. Clearly, the tale evolved depending on what message the storyteller was trying to portray. Regardless of the version, the vast influence of the [[Catholic Church]] is clearly noticeable.
===Lumberjack heroes=== A number of lumberjack heroes were made famous through stories told by itinerant lumberjacks throughout Central Canada and the northern United States. These lumberjack heroes were of French-Canadian origin, and became the basis for many [[Paul Bunyan]] stories. They include tales about [[Joseph Montferrand]] ("Joe Muffreau" or "[[Big Joe Mufferaw]]"), [[Julius Neville]], [[Louis Cyr]], and [[Napoleon La Rue]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Edmonds|first=Michael|title=Out of the Northwoods: The Many Lives of Paul Bunyan, With More Than 100 Logging Camp Tales|date=2010|publisher=Wisconsin Historical Society|isbn=9780870204715|page=55}}</ref>
==Superstitions== Other aspects of [[Quebec]] folklore include superstitions surrounding objects, events, and dreams. In essence, these stem from the belief in both [[Left-Hand Path and Right-Hand Path|White Magic]] and [[Black Magic]], where the former is seen to be beneficial and seeks to bring about positive outcomes, and the latter being essentially malicious, sinister, and all-around [[evil]] (sometimes also called [[witchcraft]]).<ref name="Magic">{{cite book |title=Magie et Sorcellerie Populaires au Québec |last=DesRuisseaux |first=Pierre |year=1976 |publisher= Triptyque |location=Montreal, Quebec}}</ref> Although Christianity had slowly chipped away at most forms of magic, the populace still held on to its various superstitions for generations. Where religion provides Quebec with a societal structure, these beliefs sought to predict the future, to help alleviate fear of the unknown.<ref name="Magic"/>
Listed below are objects along with a brief description of the superstition associated with them.<ref name="Magic"/>
* Age: A woman, regardless of marital status, will experience an important event during the year following her 31st birthday. * Bonhomme sept-heures: This man is said to kidnap children who are out of bed after seven o'clock at night. He hides underneath balconies and, equipped with a mask and a bag in which to dispose the children, enters a home after the clock strikes seven. * Freckles: Having freckles on your arms is a sign of sensuality. * Hairbrush: If a young woman drops her hairbrush, she'll lose her fiancé. * Needle: ** If you lose your needle, you will also lose your horse. ** If you drop a needle and it sticks itself into the ground, then someone is thinking ill of you. * Stars: Count nine stars nine nights in a row, and the last star will point towards your future husband.
==Research into Quebec folklore== Interest in researching and classifying folklore began during the late 19th century. [[Marius Barbeau]] established himself as one of Canada's foremost folklorists during the early 20th century. [[Luc Lacourcière]] founded the Folklore Archives at [[Laval University]] in [[Quebec City]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Linteau|first=Paul-André|title=Quebec Since 1930|date=1991|publisher=James Lorimer & Co.|isbn=9781550282962|page=119}}</ref> Laval University offers an academic folklore studies program.<ref>{{cite book|title=Forum Mondial UNESCO-OMPI Sur la Protection Du Folklore|date=1998|publisher=Unesco, World Intellectual Property Organization|isbn=9789280507553|page=80}}</ref> The [[Folklore Studies Association of Canada]] has also done extensive work related to preserving Quebec folklore.
The [[Association Québécoise des Loisirs Folkloriques]], based in Montreal, runs a number of programs for the public year-round, as well as publishing literature and recordings of folklore. The [[Canadian Museum of History]] in [[Gatineau]], the [[McCord Museum]] in Montreal, and the [[Musée Québécois de culture populaire]] in [[Trois-Rivières]] have extensive holdings related to Quebec folklore and folk artifacts.
==See also== *[[Canadian folklore]] *[[Dalbec]] *[[French folklore]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Culture of Quebec]] [[Category:Canadian folklore]] [[Category:Folklore by region]]

'''Francois Dufrene''' ('''François Dufrêne''') (born Paris, September 21, 1930 - died Paris, December 12, 1982) was a French [[Nouveau réalisme|Nouveau realist]] visual artist, [[Lettrist]] and [[Ultra-Lettrist]] [[poet]]. He is primarily known as a pioneer in [[sound poetry]] and for his use of [[décollage]] within [[Nouveau réalisme]].
==Lettrist, Ultra-Lettrist and Nouveau réalisme movements== Dufrene, along with [[Gil J Wolman]] and [[Brion Gysin]], was one of the stalwarts of the experimental [[poetry]] in France. Dufrene's abstract poetry has led many to regard him as a member of the first generation [[Sound poetry|sound poets]] - following in the footsteps of [[Filippo Tommaso Marinetti]], [[Richard Huelsenbeck]], [[Hugo Ball]], [[Tristan Tzara]], [[Kurt Schwitters]] and [[Antonin Artaud]] (among others).
Francois Dufrene joined [[Isidore Isou]] and the [[Lettrisme|Lettrist movement]] in 1946 and continued to participate until 1964. Dufrene's talent was evident in the fact that he was already a member of the [[Lettrist]] Group at only 16 years old.<ref>[http://www.dufrene.net/] François Dufrene bio</ref>
Dufrene then created a [[phonetic]] poetry which breaks the structures of language he called [[Ultra-Lettrist]]. The Ultra-Lettrist movement was an art form developed by Dufrene along with Jean-Louis Brau and [[Gil J Wolman]] in the 1950s, when they split from Isidore Isou's Lettrism. Dufrene explored vocal possibilities of [[concrete music]], a form of expression based on spontaneity directly recorded to tape, exploiting the [[noise music]] of sound, meaning and [[nonsense]].
Dufrene became friends with [[Yves Klein]] in 1950 and with [[Raymond Hains]] and [[Jacques Villeglé]] in 1954.<ref>[http://www.dufrene.net/] François Dufrene bio</ref> In 1957 he discovered décollage and in 1960 - with [[Pierre Restany]], [[Yves Klein]], [[Jean Tinguely]], [[Arman]], Hains and Villeglé - and helped found the art group known as [[Nouveau réalisme]]. He is considered one of the important artists in that [[Neo-Dada]] art movement.
==Crirythme performances== Dufrene earned fame for his performances called ''Crirythmes'',<ref>[http://ubumexico.centro.org.mx/sound/poesia_sonora/Poesia-Sonora_11_Francois-Dufrene.mp3] audio file of ''Crirythme'' on [[Ubuweb]]</ref> which was in a vocal style of [[sound art]] different from those of his contemporaries.<ref>[http://www.art-contemporain.eu.org/base/chronologie/1223.html] Main exhibitions</ref> The ''Crirythme'' work inspired generations of experimental poets, such as [[Henri Chopin]], [[Bernard Heidsieck]], [[Ake Hodell]], [[Charles Amirkhanian]], [[Bob Cobbing]], [[Gregory Whitehead]], [[bpNichol]], [[Tracie Morris]], [[Clive Fencott]], [[Ada Verdun Howell]], [[Mitch Corber]] and [[Jaap Blonk]].
==Film without a screen== Dufrene is the author of a film called ''Tambours du jugement premier'' (''Drums of the first judgment'') (1952), a fantasy film presented on the sidelines of the Cannes Film Festival the same year. In 1973 it was presented at the Atelier de Création (France Culture), in 1981 as part of the exhibition ''Paris-Paris'' at the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]], and in 1982 at ''Thirty Years of Experimental Cinema in France'' also at the Centre Georges Pompidou.
''Tambours du jugement premier'' is a "film" without screen, projector or film, which eliminates not only the dictatorship of the image over the word, but abandons the projected image altogether, because it’s no longer a matter of perceiving it passively, but rather one of imagining or recreating it. Originally however, Dufrene had indeed anticipated a visual part of the film, never taken to fruition, which was not even complete when the [[Screenplay|script]] was published. The weight of the work lay clearly in its [[soundtrack]], which is all that the initial project finally became. It could therefore be considered a piece of [[sound art]] rather than a [[film]] in the conventional sense.
The first presentation of ''Tambours du jugement premier'' as an ''imaginary film without screen or film'' took place in [[Cannes]] in 1952, at the Alexandre III cinema. The scant resources it required enabled the imaginary film to be improvised. The voices were situated in the four corners of the hall and while the performers recited the texts, the house lights flashed on and off and the [[stage curtain]] opened and closed repeatedly. Dufrene’s ''Tambours du jugement premier'' is a play on the exhaustion of [[cinematographic]] medium, situating itself as a film beyond [[Movie projector|film projection]] machinery. The frustration of the public’s expectations - and its invitation to the viewer’s imagination - is what creates a rupture and liberation from the impositions of the standard image.
The soundtrack for ''Tambours du jugement premier'' contains an important phonetic work which includes almost all of the compositions and scores that Dufrene had produced up to that time in the form of lettrist poems and sung aphorisms as experimental [[sound poetry]]. The compositions renounced any type of discursive content and consisted in improvisations recorded on a [[tape recorder]], employing all the possible capabilities of voice and body.
==Works== *''Bottom'' (1960), torn posters pasted on wood; in the collection of the [[Toulon]] Art Museum *[http://ubumexico.centro.org.mx/sound/poesia_sonora/Poesia-Sonora_11_Francois-Dufrene.mp3] François Dufrêne's ''Crirythmes'' on ''Cramps Records'' LP (1975), a disk curated by Maurizio Nannucci with assistance by Arrigo Lora-Totino and produced by [[Giancarlo Bigazzi]]
==Further reading== *Dufrene, Hains, Rotella, Villegle, Vostell: ''Plakatabrisse aus der Sammlung Cremer'', Staatsgalerie Stuttgart 1971 *Benjamin Buchloh u.a.: ''Hains, Villegle, Dufrene, Rotella, Decollage: les affichistes'', Zabriskie, New York 1990 *''TPL'', François Dufrêne, Alain Jouffroy, [[Wolf Vostell]], Verlag Der Kalender, Wuppertal 1961.<ref>[http://artistsbooks.info/AB_Vostell%20Wolf.html TPL, 1961]</ref> * ''Poesie der Großstadt. Die Affichisten''. Bernard Blistène, Fritz Emslander, Esther Schlicht, Didier Semin, Dominique Stella. Snoeck, Köln 2014, {{ISBN|978-3-9523990-8-8}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== *''Dictionary of Modern and Contemporary Art'', Paris, Éditions Hazan, 2006, p. 217
==External links== * [http://www.dufrene.net] François Dufrene Official Site * [http://www.art-contemporain.eu.org/base/chronologie/1223.html] Main exhibitions * [http://www.ubu.com/sound/dufrene.html] Francois Dufrene sound at [[Ubuweb]]

{{Infobox theatre | name = Goodspeed Opera House | image = GoodspeedOperaHouse.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = The Goodspeed Opera House from the Connecticut River | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption= | address = 6 Main Street | city = [[East Haddam, Connecticut|East Haddam]], [[Connecticut]] | country = [[United States]] | designation = | architect = | owner = Goodspeed Musicals | tenant = | operator = | capacity = | type = Regional theatre | opened = October 24, 1877 <!--{{Start date|YYYY|MM|FF|df=y}}--> | reopened = June 8, 1963 | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = {{URL|http://www.goodspeed.org}} {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name = Goodspeed Opera House | coordinates ={{Coord|41|27|6.33|N|72|27|45.06|W|region:US-CT|display=title,inline}} | area = | built = 1876-77 | architect = Jabez Comstock<ref name=nrhp/> | architecture = | added = July 30, 1971 | refnum = 71000901<ref name=nrhp>{{NRISref|2010a}}</ref> | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = Private | nrhp_type2 = cp | nocat = yes | designated_nrhp_type2 = April 29, 1983 | partof = [[East Haddam Historic District]] | partof_refnum = 83001273 }} }}
'''Goodspeed Musicals''' is a non-profit organization dedicated to the preservation and advancement of musical theater and the creation of new works, located in [[East Haddam, Connecticut]]. A distinctive feature of the view from the [[Connecticut River]], the Goodspeed Opera House is the birthplace of some of the world's most famous musicals, including ''[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]'', ''[[Man of La Mancha]]'' and ''[[Shenandoah (musical)|Shenandoah]]''.
== Goodspeed Opera House == The Opera House was originally built by a local merchant and banker, William Goodspeed. Construction began in 1876 and finished in 1877. Despite the name, it was not in fact an [[opera house]], but rather a venue for presenting plays. Its first play, ''Charles II'', opened on October 24, 1877. After William Goodspeed's death, the opera house fell into disrepair, facing a series of less glamorous uses—from a militia base during [[World War I]] to a [[general store]] and a Department of Transportation storage facility.
The building is unique for a theater. The theater itself is actually located on the top two floors of the building making for interesting and sometimes difficult scenery and show load-ins. Scenery is loaded-in from the dock area up a vacant elevator shaft that is now outfitted with a winch system to haul the scenery up to the stage level. Much care has to be taken in order to get the scenery up the shaft without scratching or ruining the scenery. One story told around Goodspeed is that while loading in the scenery for Annie's original pre-Broadway run, a strong gust of wind took a large piece of scenery out of the hands of the loaders and blew it into the Connecticut River.
== Goodspeed Musicals ==
Goodspeed Musicals was formed in 1959 by a group of concerned citizens after the state of Connecticut had condemned the building. The state agreed to sell the building to the group for one dollar, provided they acquire enough funding to restore and maintain it. The restoration project took nearly four years, and the Goodspeed Opera House was rededicated on June 8, 1963. The first performance in the new opera house was ''[[Oh, Lady! Lady!]]'' Under the direction of [[Michael P. Price]] since 1968, Goodspeed Musicals has sent 19 productions to Broadway.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/people/Goodspeed-Opera-House/#.U7LoUbGzmYk|title=Goodspeed Opera House Theatre Credits|publisher=}}</ref> Goodspeed productions have won more than a dozen [[Tony Award]]s, while Goodspeed Musicals itself has won two special Tonys, one for outstanding contributions to American Musicals and the other for outstanding achievement by a regional theatre.
In 1984, Goodspeed Musicals added a second performance venue—the [[Norma Terris Theatre]]—in nearby [[Chester, Connecticut]]. While the main stage presents a mixture of revivals and new musicals as part of its 3 production season, The Norma Terris also presents three new musicals each season. Several original plays debuted there or at the opera house before going on to [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] and winning [[Tony Award]]s.
In addition to the two theaters, Goodspeed Musicals pursues its mission through the Max Showalter Center for Education in Musical Theatre, which offers internships and new writers' residency programs, as well as the Scherer Library of Musical Theatre, which houses the largest musical theatre research facility in the United States. Goodspeed Musicals has also built state-of-the-art production facilities including scenery shops, costume shops and a large costume storage facility.
Critic fellows from the [[Eugene O'Neill Theater Center]] in Waterford, CT travel to the Goodspeed each summer to practice reviewing full productions.
Tours of many of the Goodspeed facilities can be scheduled in advance for a small fee. Tickets to the opera house or theatre productions should be ordered in advance as most performances in the relatively small theater sell-out quickly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvisit.com/tours/goodspeed-opera-house-tour/summary/2236 |title=Visit CT |work=Visit CT |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714194527/http://www.ctvisit.com/tours/goodspeed-opera-house-tour/summary/2236 |archivedate=2014-07-14 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Connecticut}} *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Middlesex County, Connecticut]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Short description|Painting by Edward Hopper}} {{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork/wikidata | image = Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper.JPG }} '''''Hotel Lobby''''' is an [[oil painting]] on [[canvas]] by American [[Realist visual arts|realist]] painter [[Edward Hopper]]; it is held in the collection of the [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] (IMA), in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], United States.<ref name="HotelLobby">{{cite web | author= | year=2010 | title=Hotel Lobby | work=Collections | publisher =[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] | url=http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/hotel-lobby-hopper-edward | accessdate = 14 April 2010}}</ref>
==Description==
The painting depicts two women and a man in the lobby of a hotel. On the right is a woman with blond hair and a blue dress, sitting with her legs crossed and reading a book. To the left sits an older woman with a red dress, a coat and a hat. A man stands next to her, facing forward, with a suit on and an overcoat draped over his right arm. On the left wall, above the woman, is a framed landscape painting. A clerk behind the reception desk is barely visible in the shadows.<ref name="HotelLobby"/>
==Context==
''Hotel Lobby'' is a signature piece in Hopper's work, displaying his classic themes of [[wiktionary:alienation|alienation]] and [[wiktionary:brevity|brevity]].<ref name="HotelLobby"/> The Hoppers traveled frequently, staying in many motels and hotels throughout his career. This is one of two works in his catalog that depicts a hotel, the other being ''Hotel Window'' (1955). The older couple are believed to represent Hopper and his wife, at that date in their 60s.<ref name="Warkel">{{cite book |last=Warkel |first=Harriet G. |coauthors= |title=Paper to Paint: Edward Hopper's ''Hotel Lobby'' |publisher=[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] |year=2009 |month= |isbn=978-0-936260-84-6}}</ref> The hotel guests have been described as being "both traveling and suspended in time,"<ref name="HotelLobby"/> reflecting a stoic and dramatic feeling, reminiscent of the [[film noir]] movies Hopper might have seen and the complex structure and feeling of works by [[Edgar Degas]]. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper Detail 2.JPG| thumb| Light detail]] --> The painting utilizes harsh light and rigid lines to create a "carefully constructed" uncomfortable environment. The elevated and [[theatrical]] [[wikt:vantage point|vantage point]] of the painting may be derived from Hopper's love of [[Broadway theatre]] which he often watched from the balcony.<ref name="HotelLobby"/>
===Sketches===
Before he created the ''Hotel Lobby'' Hopper drew ten studies of the work, which are in the collection of the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]], as a gift for his wife, Josephine.<ref name="Warkel"/><ref name="ArtistPanel">{{cite journal |last1=Meyerowitz |first1=Joel |last2=Segal |first2=George |last3=Bailey |first3=William |last4=Levin |first4=Gail |year=1981 |title=Artists' Panel |journal=[[Art Journal (CAA)|Art Journal]] |volume=41 |issue=2 |pages=151–153 |publisher=[[College Art Association]] |doi= |jstor=776464 }}</ref><ref name="IndianapolisMonth1">{{cite journal |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |year=2008 |title=Indianapolis Museum of Art |journal=[[Indianapolis Monthly]] |volume= |issue=September |pages=170 |publisher=[[Emmis Communications]] |doi= }}</ref> Nine of the ten studies are described as:
*Study one was believed to have been executed while Hopper in a hotel lobby observed two seated figures separated by a lamp and table. That wall features a curtained opening, a registration desk and a painting on the wall with the stairwell and railing on the left. *Study two lacks the table and lamp and includes a second painting, which is separated from the other by a wall sconce, and one figure. *Study three depicts the stairwell being moved into the background. A figure believed to be male stands in the open doorway to the left of the stairs while a woman sits to the left of the doorway with an empty chair, a painting on the wall and a tiled floor. *Study four is more refined and has greater detail. The stairs are now removed with three people on the left: two seated figures next to a standing man. The rear doorway has a curtain, columns are on the reception desk, the ceiling appears to be beamed, a second painting is on the wall and a stripe is added to the floor. *Study five is double sided. One side appears to be an abandoned diagram of a room. The reverse side shows the room with a more detailed revolving door and a return to a single, framed painting on the wall. The reception desk columns are more detailed, and the stripe on the floor is darkened. *Study six is missing the seated figure from the left with only three remaining and in more detail. The figures and the elevator are in their final locations. *Study seven shows the fourth figure reappearing by the couple. The ceiling, desk, revolving door, curtained doorway and elevator all have greater detail. The couple also appears to be having a conversation. *Study eight was created to further detail the older woman's clothing and hands, showing her with a gold [[glove]]. *Study nine is a partial sketch of the younger woman who is reading, which shares the page with sketch eight, in greater detail. Until this sketch the other seated figure was a man.<ref name="Warkel"/>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper Detail 3.JPG| thumb| Blonde woman detail]] --> These studies show the older couple communicating, only to cease their conversation in the final painting and reading man is replaced with a blonde young woman reading in the final painting.<ref name="Saetre">{{cite news |title=Fame is no cure for fear, Hopper exhibit shows |author=Julie Cope Saetre |url=http://assets3.indy.com/posts/10478 |newspaper=Indy.com |date=28 August 2008 |accessdate=14 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724055209/http://assets3.indy.com/posts/10478 |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> The modeling for both women in the painting was done by his wife Josephine. After their marriage in 1920 she insisted on being the model for all of his female figures.<ref name="Elovich">{{cite journal |last1=Elovich |first1=Richard |last2= |first2= |year=1981 |title=London. Edward Hopper |journal=[[The Burlington Magazine]] |volume=123 |issue=935 |pages=111 |publisher=The Burlington Magazine Publications, Inc. |doi= |jstor=880286 }}</ref>
The coat the older woman wears is based on a [[fur coat]] owned by Hopper's wife, a coat she often wore to openings and a rare find in the Hopper's frugal household. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper Detail 1.JPG| thumb|left| Woman in red detail]] --> The red dress that the older woman wears (that Jo, in her journal, describes as "coral") signifies anger and extroversion, while the blue dress worn by the younger woman shows youth and distance. Throughout Hopper's sketches the clerk does not appear until the final painting. Under X-ray it can be seen that Hopper did little to change the canvas once he began work. Most alterations were made in the position of the young woman's head and in outlines of some areas in dark blue paint. A partial underdrawing was found but little detail remains.
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper Detail 4.JPG| thumb| |Hopper detail]] --> Hopper was known to model for himself for figures, as in ''Nighthawks'', leading some to believe he may have modeled for the male figure in ''Hotel Lobby''.
One of the few paintings by Hopper to lack windows, ''Hotel Lobby'' utilizes light from the revolving door and an unseen area from between the ceiling beams.<ref name="Warkel"/>
==Reception==
In 1945 Hopper was awarded the [[Logan Medal of the Arts]] and a $500 [[honorarium]] for ''Hotel Lobby''.<ref name="Levin">{{cite book |last=Levin |first=Gail |coauthors= |title=Edward Hopper: An intimate biography |publisher=[[University of California Press]] |year=1998 |month= |isbn=0-520-21475-7}}</ref><ref name="ArtInstitute1">{{cite journal |last1=Levin |first1=Gail |last2=Hopper |first2=Edward |year=1996 |title=Edward Hopper's "Nighthawks", Surrealism, and the War |journal=Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=195 |publisher=[[Art Institute of Chicago]] |doi= |jstor=4104321 }}</ref> The painting was chosen by a jury composed of [[Juliana Force]], then director of the [[Whitney Museum of American Art|Whitney Museum]], and artists [[Raphael Soyer]] and [[Reginald Marsh (artist)|Reginald Marsh]].<ref name="ArtInstitute1"/> In regards to the painting, Chicago critic [[Clarence Joseph Bulliet|C.J. Bulliet]] stated that "Mr. Hopper is getting a little lazy about the excellent formula he has hit. ''Hotel Lobby'' is typical Hopper, but Hopper that has lost something of its kick."<ref name="Levin"/> The artwork has been compared to Hopper's earlier work ''Summer Interior'' (1909), a work that helped to create Hopper's signature style; an intimate setting, simple lines and geometry, flat color usage and moody light. A shadowy figure and a sensual woman each make another visit in ''Hotel Lobby'' as seen in ''Summer Interior''.<ref name="Warkel"/>
==Ownership and exhibition history== The painting was in the collection of Henry Hope from [[Bloomington, Indiana]].<ref name="HotelLobby"/>
From June until December 2006 the Whitney Museum, which has the largest holding of Hopper's works in the world, displayed ''Hotel Lobby'' alongside their own works and key loans such as ''[[Nighthawks]]'' (1942) and ''New York Movie'' (1939).<ref name="Whitney">{{cite web | author= | year=2011 | title=Edward Hopper | work=Exhibitions | publisher=Whitney Museum of American Art | url=http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/EdwardHopper | accessdate=14 April 2010}}</ref><ref name="Vogel">{{cite news |title=Hoppers Come and Go In a Whitney Show |author=Carol Vogel |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=6 October 2006 }}</ref><ref name="Ronnen">{{cite news |title=Tiroche sale opens tomorrow |author=Meir Ronnen |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=7 July 2006 }}</ref> ''Hotel Lobby'' is currently on display in the Indianapolis Museum of Art's [[American scene painting|American Scene]] Gallery.<ref name="HotelLobby"/> In 2008 the IMA exhibited the work alongside the ten studies on loan from the Whitney in ''Edward Hopper: Paper to Paint'', which ran until January 2009.<ref name="IndianapolisMonth1"/>
===Publications===
In 1996 ''Hotel Lobby'' was used as the paperback cover for the book ''Hotel Paradise'' by [[Martha Grimes]].<ref name="Grimes">{{cite book |last=Grimes |first=Martha |coauthors= |title=Hotel Paradise |publisher=[[Random House]] |year=1996 |month= |isbn=978-0-345-39425-5}}</ref> The painting also appears in ''City Limits: Crime, consumer culture and the urban experience'' by [[Keith Hayward]].<ref name="Hayward">{{cite book |last=Hayward |first=Keith |coauthors= |title=City limits: Crime, consumer culture and the urban experience |publisher=[[Psychology Press]] |year=2004 |month= |isbn=1-904385-03-6}}</ref>
==See also==
*''[[Automat (painting)|Automat]]'', 1927 *''[[Chop Suey (painting)|Chop Suey]]'', 1929 *''[[Nighthawks]]'', Hopper's most famous painting. *''[[Office at Night]]'', 1940 *''[[Office in a Small City]]'', 1953
==References==
{{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading==
*Tallack, D. (2002). 'Waiting, waiting': the hotel lobby, in the modern city. ''The Hieroglyphics of Space''. [[Psychology Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-415-19892-9}} Discusses the ideas behind hotel lobbies as symbols of culture, including the painting. *Warkel, Harriet. ''Paper to Paint: Edward Hopper’s "Hotel Lobby."'' [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]]. 2009. {{ISBN|978-0-936260-84-6}} Catalog that coordinated with the 2008 exhibition.
==External links== *[http://huntingnighthawks.blogspot.com/2008/06/13.html ''14 A Hotel Lobby''], Kevin Grandfield talks about his visit to the IMA to view the Hopper's in their collection
{{Hopper}} {{IMAart}}

{{For|the theatre in Moldova|Bălți National Theatre}} {{Infobox theatre |name = Vasile Alecsandri National Theatre
Teatrul Național „Vasile Alecsandri” din Iași |image = Teatrul Național „Vasile Alecsandri” din Iași.JPG |image_size = 250px |caption = Front view |pushpin_map = |pushpin_map_caption = |address = 18 Agatha Bârsescu Street |city = [[Iași]] |country = Romania |architect = [[Fellner & Helmer]] |owner = |capacity = Large Hall 850 seats
The Cube Theatre 180 seats
Teofil Vâlcu Hall 100 seats
The Theatre Plant 100 seats |type = [[List of national theatres|National theatre]] |opened = 1840 |yearsactive = |rebuilt = 1894-1896 |closed = |othernames = Great Theatre of Moldavia |production = Fântâna Blanduziei http://www.imagoromaniae.ro/articole/teatre-edificii-societati-si-asociatii-culturale.htmlhttp://infotravelguide.ro/2010/06/teatrul-national-vasile-alecsandri-din-iasi/ |currentuse = |website = [http://www.teatrulnationaliasi.ro www.teatrulnationaliasi.ro] }} The '''Iași National Theatre''' ([[Romanian language|Romanian]]: Teatrul Național Vasile Alecsandri) in [[Iași]], [[Romania]], is the oldest national theatre and one of the most prestigious theatrical institutions in Romania. In 1956, it was given the name of the renowned Romanian playwright and poet [[Vasile Alecsandri]]. ==History== [[File:TNI 1846.jpg|thumb|left|The old building of the National Theatre, 1846]] One of the first theatrical performance in Romanian language, was organized by [[Gheorghe Asachi]], and held in the capital of [[Moldavia]], Jassy/Iași, on 27 September 1816.[https://books.google.com/books?id=-0mJ7blUGtQC&pg=PA166&lpg=PA166&dq=first+theatrical+performance+in+Romanian&source=bl&ots=tiSaCCg2J7&sig=-4Md-LKCHVTN2O_rilvV5Ta-m9c&hl=en&ei=NZAvTK8chJY468DZ1AE&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=first%20theatrical%20performance%20in%20Romanian&f=false History of the literary cultures of East-Central Europe] In 1834, a Romanian production took place in Iași on the stage of the Théâtre de varieté, built in 1832 for the French Fouraux troupe. The National Theatre was founded on 15 May 1840, as the ''Great Theatre of Moldavia'', when the Romanian language troupe, led by [[Costache Caragiale|Costache Caragiali]], was united with the French troupe, under a single direction of [[Vasile Alecsandri]] and the management of Costache Caragiali.[https://books.google.com/books?id=8qMTPAPFGXUC&pg=PA933&lpg=PA933&dq=first+first+theatre+performance+Romanian&source=bl&ots=uK_HV7btXh&sig=64VSDq6lqoxuIc1EYzH9dt2xN_c&hl=en&ei=nn8vTITwL8j_OcuDiIEC&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CDQQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=first%20first%20theatre%20performance%20Romanian&f=false The Cambridge guide to theatre] On 22 December 1846, a new audience hall was inaugurated in the former mansion of [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Prince]] [[Mihail Sturdza]], on the [[Seven hills of Iași|Hill of Copou]].[http://en.teatrulnationaliasi.ro/pages/theatre History] ==Building== On the night of 17/18 February 1888, the theatre building was destroyed by the fire. The efforts to build the new theatre edifice culminated in 1894 when a contract was signed with the Viennese architects [[Ferdinand Fellner|Ferdinand Fellner and Hermann Helmer]], who designed several theatres and palaces across Europe, including the theatres in: [[Cluj-Napoca]], [[Oradea]], [[Timișoara]] and [[Chernivtsi]] (Romanian: Cernăuți). [[File:Teatrul Naţional Interior.jpg|thumb|left|The main auditorium]] For the building work, a contract was signed with a Bucharest company, and the power station was built by a company from Berlin. The Theatre’s power station also supplied with electricity the 12 electric-arc lamps lighting the Theatre Square, marking the beginning of electrification in the city of Iași. The works to building took two years, and on 1 and 2 December 1896, the inauguration festivities took place with [[Alexander Flechtenmacher|Flechtenmacher]]'s ''National Overture'', the vaudevilles ''Muza de la Burdujeni'' (''The Muse from Burdujeni'') by [[Costache Negruzzi]] and ''Cinel-cinel'' (''The Riddle'') by Vasile Alecsandri, as well as the verse comedy ''Poetul romantic'' (''The Romantic Poet'') by [[Matei Millo]]. Nowadays, the building also hosts the [[Iași Romanian National Opera]]. The Iași National Theatre building is listed in the [[National Register of Historic Monuments in Romania|National Register of Historic Monuments]].[http://patrimoniu.gov.ro/images/LMI/LMI-2010_IS.pdf The Romanian Register of Historical Monuments in Iași County] ===Architecture=== With a [[Neoclassic style|Neoclassic]] exterior and a richly decorated interior in [[Rococo]] and [[Baroque]] styles, the building is considered one of the most elegant in Romania.[http://www.romaniatourism.com/iasi.html IASI - City Highlights] at romaniatourism.com The main auditorium is organised in stalls, boxes and a balcony. The curtain painted by the Viennese M. Lenz, presents in the middle, an allegory of life with its three stages and, to the right side, the allegory of [[Greater Romania|Romanian Unification]]. The left-hand side, painted by Lenz’s apprentice, differs from the rest of the curtain in style and colouring. The ceiling and the iron curtain were painted by Alexander Goltz. The iron curtain, which completely separates the scene from the hall, shows ornaments placed symmetrically, while the ceiling has as a narrative basis the Archetypal Story, shown in paradisiacal allegories, with nymphs and cupids framed in rococo stucco.[https://sites.google.com/site/teatrulnationaliasi/home/istoric The main theatre building] The 1,418 electric lights and the chandelier with 109 Venetian crystal lamps light up a playhouse with a unique architectural personality. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|National Theatre in Iaşi}} * [http://www.teatrulnationaliasi.ro/en/ Official website] {{coord missing|Romania}} {{Iași Landmarks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Iasi National Theatre}} [[Category:Historic monuments in Iași County|Theatre]] [[Category:Culture in Iași|Theatre]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Iași|Theatre]] [[Category:Theatres in Iași]] [[Category:National theatres]] [[Category:Neoclassical architecture]] [[Category:Fellner & Helmer buildings]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1896]] [[Category:Event venues established in 1840]]

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
'''Industry of the Ordinary''' (IOTO) is a two-person conceptual art collaborative, made up of Chicago-based artists and educators Adam Brooks and Mathew Wilson.<ref name=Heartney>{{cite book|last=Heartney|first=Eleanor|title=Industry of the Ordinary: Sic Transit Gloria Mundi 2003-2013|year=2012|publisher=Chicago Cultural Center|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-9852964-0-7|pages=96–101|authorlink=Between Done and Not Done}}</ref> Their work is usually performative or sculptural, often incorporating audience participation and interaction with the artists.<ref name=WBEZ>{{cite web|last=Cuddy|first=Alison|title=Art and Industry: August 20-26|url=http://www.wbez.org/blogs/alison-cuddy/2012-08/zaftig-retrospective-art-duo-industry-ordinary-101810|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref>
== About == Industry of the Ordinary document their projects at their website, where their manifesto states, "Through sculpture, text, photography, video, sound and performance, Industry of the Ordinary are dedicated to an exploration and celebration of the customary, the everyday, and the usual. Their emphasis is on challenging pejorative notions of the ordinary and, in doing so, moving beyond the quotidian."<ref>{{cite web|last=Industry of the Ordinary|title=Manifesto|url=http://www.industryoftheordinary.com/html/manifesto.html|accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref> Industry of the Ordinary formed in 2003. IOTO's work appears in diverse forms, including performances tailored for specific exhibitions and performance art openings, artist-driven interventions on the streets of cities throughout the US and internationally, and public works commissioned by the [[Nebraska State Historical Society]],<ref name=Heartney /> the City of Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events (DCASE)<ref name=DCASE>{{cite web|last=Gatziolis|first=Cindy|title=Seeking the Art of the Ordinary|url=http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/provdrs/attractions_eventsandexhibitions/news/2012/aug/seeking_the_art_oftheordinary.html|publisher=City of Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref> and the Billboard Art Project,<ref name=Billboards>{{cite web|last=Billboard Art Project|title=Baton Rouge, LA Participating Artists|url=http://billboardartproject.org/cities/baton_rouge.html|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref> among others. They have shown work at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago]],<ref name=MCA>{{cite web|last=MCA Chicago|title=UBS 12 x 12 New Artists/New Work|url=http://www.mcachicago.org/exhibitions/now/2013/207|accessdate=19 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130704075314/http://www.mcachicago.org/exhibitions/now/2013/207|archivedate=4 July 2013|df=}}</ref> the [[Chicago Cultural Center]], the [[Art Institute of Chicago]], the [[Hyde Park Art Center]],<ref name=HPAC>{{cite web|last=Hyde Park Art Center|title=Exhibitions: Googling Ordinary|url=http://www.hydeparkart.org/exhibitions/emgoogling-ordinaryem|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref> and the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles]].
== Themes == Industry of the Ordinary's work deals with themes of faith, freedom, politics, youth culture, celebrity, competitive sports, sex and drinking.<ref name="Catalog Interview">{{cite book|last=MacKenzie|first=Duncan|title=Industry of the Ordinary: Sic Transit Gloria Mundi 2003-2013|year=2012|publisher=Chicago Cultural Center|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-9852964-0-7|pages=176–183|authorlink=Feeling Ordinary}}</ref> They often employ collaborative strategies, as in their piece ''39 Verbs'', for which they commissioned fellow arts professionals to create 39 works inspired by arbitrarily assigned verbs taken from their previous works' titles.<ref name="39 Verbs">{{cite web|last=Ruiz|first=Steve|title=Minireview: Industry of the Ordinary @ Packer Schopf|url=http://chicagoartreview.wordpress.com/2009/11/14/minireview-industry-of-the-ordinary-packer-schopf/|publisher=Chicago Art Review|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref> This emphasis on collaboration subverts traditional conceptions of art creation as highly individualistic, calling into question the elitism of the institutional art world. Works like ''Celebrity and the Peculiar,'' an installation of oxygen tents suffused by humidifiers with various celebrity perfumes, question popular culture's obsession with notoriety and our individual attempts to identify with celebrities.<ref name="Celebrity and the Peculiar">{{cite book|last=Molon|first=Dominic|title=Industry of the Ordinary: Sic Transit Gloria Mundi 2003-2013|year=2012|publisher=Chicago Cultural Center|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-9852964-0-7|pages=81–83|authorlink=The Stifling Smell of Success}}</ref> IOTO's preoccupation with public interaction and stated intention that their work be completed by the creative interpretation and engagement of the audience has led some critics to categorize their work within the umbrella of [[Relational Aesthetics]].<ref name="Newcity Review">{{cite web|last=Stabler|first=Bert|title=Review: Industry of the Ordinary/Chicago Cultural Center|url=http://art.newcity.com/2012/08/28/review-industry-of-the-ordinarychicago-cultural-center/|publisher=Newcity|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref> Their work has also been linked to the [[Situationist International]] and [[Fluxus]] movements. Their public interventions, usually ephemeral and existing afterwards only in the form of documentary photographs, videos, or text, has also been compared to the [[Happenings]] of the 1960s. One piece, ''Re-Work (for Allan Kaprow, [[Marina Abramović]] and [[Philip-Lorca diCorcia]]),'' re-imagines [[Allan Kaprow]]'s delegated performance, ''Work''. In his original, Kaprow hired professional house painters to paint and re-paint the hallway of a gallery space. For their ''Re-Work'' at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles]], IOTO hired two sex workers to perform the same task while wearing their "professional" attire. Just as Kaprow's piece questioned the distinction of artist by contracting out the actual art-making process, IOTO's piece questions our assumptions about the nature of, and our subsequent judgements of, certain types of labor.<ref name=Heartney />
== ''Sic Transit Gloria Mundi'' == Industry of the Ordinary's mid-career retrospective, ''Sic Transit Gloria Mundi'', was shown at the [[Chicago Cultural Center]] from August 2012 to February 2013. It was an exhibition of many of their works to that point, as well as several new pieces and a series of commissioned performances and installations which occurred throughout the run of the show. One of the elements of the show, the ''Portrait Project'', consisted of 71 portraits of Industry of the Ordinary, commissioned from 71 different artists in various media. Another piece, ''Everyone'', was a projected, scrolling, crowd-sourced list attempting to name every professional artist in Chicago.<ref name=WBEZ /> The show was well received, being accorded one of the spots on [[Newcity]]'s Top Five Chicago Art Exhibitions of 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last=Foumberg|first=Jason|title=Newcity's Top 5 of Everything 2012: Art|url=http://art.newcity.com/2012/12/20/newcitys-top-5-of-everything-2012-art/|publisher=Newcity|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref>

Vernissage|url=http://art.newcity.com/2012/09/20/expo-chicago-report-the-message-from-vernissage/|publisher=NewCity Art|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> : ''Foreign Affairs,'' Rapid Pulse International 2013}}</ref> :''Evil is Interesting,'' Antena, Chicago, Illinois<ref>{{cite web|title=Evil is Interesting ::: Antena House|url=http://chicagoist.com/2012/08/07/pencil_this_in_arts_crafts_at_publi.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108094002/http://chicagoist.com/2012/08/07/pencil_this_in_arts_crafts_at_publi.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 November 2017|publisher=Chicagoist|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref>
=== 2011 === :''Industry of the Ordinary,'' Watkins College of Art, Nashville, Tennessee (solo show)<ref>{{cite web|last=Nolan|first=Joe|title=Industry of the Ordinary|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/industry-of-the-ordinary/Event?oid=2336588|publisher=Nashville Scene|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> :''Wicker Park/Bucktown Mural Project,'' Chicago, Illinois (long-term installation)<ref>{{cite web|title=Orange Walls|url=http://www.wickerparkbucktown.com/art-around-wpb/orangewalls|publisher=Wicker Park/Bucktown Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=9 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130902184352/http://www.wickerparkbucktown.com/art-around-wpb/orangewalls|archivedate=2 September 2013|df=}}</ref> :''Whiskey and Kisses/Go-Betweens,'' MDW Fair, Chicago, Illinois<ref>{{cite web|last=Ruiz|first=Steve|title=MDW, Part II|url=http://www.artslant.com/chi/articles/show/28480|publisher=ArtSlant|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> :''Visual Phrasing,'' College of St. Elizabeth, Morristown, New Jersey<ref>{{cite web|title=Visual Phrasing Art Exhibition To Open At College Of Saint Elizabeth Thursday, January 20, 2011|url=http://www.cse.edu/academics/academic-areas/culture-humanities/art/news-detail.dot?id=132309|publisher=College of Saint Elizabeth|accessdate=9 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130626174717/http://www.cse.edu/academics/academic-areas/culture-humanities/art/news-detail.dot?id=132309|archivedate=26 June 2013|df=}}</ref> :''Mash Flob,'' performance series at Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, Illinois<ref>{{cite web|last=Ferro|first=Shaunacy|title=Rolling Heads: How Industry of the Ordinary mash-flobbed the MCA|url=http://art.newcity.com/2011/04/25/rolling-heads-how-industry-of-the-ordinary-mash-flobbed-the-mca/|publisher=NewCity Art|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> :''The Search,'' Andrew Rafacz Gallery, Chicago, Illinois<ref>{{cite web|title=Jason Lazarus, Angel Otero take divergent paths|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-10-05/entertainment/ct-ent-1006-jason-lazarus-review-20111005_1_divergent-paths-blank-canvas-jason-lazarus|publisher=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> :''Hang In There,'' Co-Prosperity Sphere, Chicago, Illinois<ref>{{cite web|title=Hang in There|url=http://coprosperity.org/2011/05/the-motivation-show/|publisher=Co-Prosperity Sphere|accessdate=9 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305230402/http://coprosperity.org/2011/05/the-motivation-show/|archivedate=5 March 2012|df=}}</ref> :''Work With Me,'' A+D Gallery, Chicago, Illinois<ref>{{cite web|title=Work With Me: 5th Art + Design Faculty Exhibition|url=http://www.colum.edu/ADGallery/Exhibits/work-with-me-5th-art-+-design-faculty-exhibition.php|publisher=Columbia College Chicago|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> :''Out of Site,'' public performance series organized by Defibrillator Gallery, Chicago, Illinois<ref>{{cite web|title=Industry of the Ordinary {{!}} Out of Site|url=http://www.outofsitechicago.com/industry-of-the-ordinary|publisher=Out of Site Chicago|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref>
=== 2010 === :''History as Idea,'' Nebraska State Historical Society, 1% for Art Commission, Lincoln, Nebraska (permanent installation)<ref>{{cite web|title=Nebraska State Historical Society Headquarters|url=http://www.nebraskaartscouncil.org/public_art/onepercent/state-agencies/historical_society/headquarters.html|publisher=Nebraska Arts Council|accessdate=9 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130704085554/http://www.nebraskaartscouncil.org/public_art/onepercent/state-agencies/historical_society/headquarters.html|archivedate=4 July 2013|df=}}</ref> :''Don’t Piss on Me and Tell Me It’s Raining,'' apexart, New York, New York<ref>{{cite web|title=Don't Piss on Me and Tell Me It's Raining|url=http://apexart.org/exhibitions/badatsports.htm|publisher=apexart|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> :''ORD[i]NANCE,'' Urban Environment Office, London, England<ref>{{cite web|title=ORD[i]NANCE at The Pigeon Wing|url=http://www.artrabbit.com/all/events/event/19258/ord_i_nance|publisher=ArtRabbit|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> :''ACRE: Country in the City,'' Heaven Gallery, Chicago<ref>{{cite web|last=Doble|first=Dave|title=ACRE's 1st Annual Winter Benefit|url=http://www.heavengallery.com/?q=event/2010/11/20/list/all/all|publisher=Heaven Gallery|accessdate=9 May 2013}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
=== 2009 === :''Super Market,'' Northeastern Illinois University Gallery, Chicago (solo show)<ref>{{cite web|last=Weinberg|first=Lauren|title=Collective bargains|url=http://www.timeoutchicago.com/arts-culture/art-design/68349/collective-bargains|publisher=Time Out Chicago|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref>
=== 2008 === :''12x12,'' Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago (solo show)<ref>{{cite web|title=UBS 12 x 12: New Artists/New Work: Industry of the Ordinary|url=http://www.mcachicago.org/exhibitions/past/2008/207|publisher=Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago|accessdate=9 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024163524/http://mcachicago.org/exhibitions/past/2008/207|archivedate=24 October 2013|df=}}</ref> :''Allan Kaprow–Art as Life,'' Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles<ref>{{cite web|title=Art Galleries Press Release, April 2008|url=http://www.pitzer.edu/offices/galleries/docs/pr-industry_ordinary.html|publisher=Pitzer Art Galleries|accessdate=9 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130626182029/http://www.pitzer.edu/offices/galleries/docs/pr-industry_ordinary.html|archivedate=26 June 2013|df=}}</ref> :''Journeys,'' Chicago Public Library Public Art Commission, Chicago, Illinois (permanent installation)<ref>{{cite web|title=City of Chicago :: Branch Library Installations|url=http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/chicago_s_publicartbranchlibraryinstallations.html|publisher=City of Chicago|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> :''Celebrity and The Peculiar,'' Gahlberg Gallery, College of DuPage, Illinois (solo show)<ref>{{cite web|last=Gunn|first=Dan|title=Review: Industry of the Ordinary/Gahlberg Gallery|url=http://art.newcity.com/2008/02/07/review-industry-of-the-ordinarygahlberg-gallery/|publisher=NewCity Art|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref>

page.title: Intellectual property protection in consumer electronics industry

revision.comment: Alter: last. Add: isbn, year. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2016}}
[[Intellectual property]] (IP) refers to creations of the mind, such as [[Invention|inventions]]; literary and artistic works; designs; and symbols, names and images used in commerce.
IP is protected in law by, for example, [[Patent|patents]], [[copyright]] and [[Trademark|trademarks]], which enable people to earn recognition or financial benefit from what they invent or create. By striking the right balance between the interests of innovators and the wider public interest, the IP system aims to foster an environment in which creativity and innovation can flourish.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.wipo.int/about-ip/en/ | title = What is Intellectual Property | last = | first = | date = | website = | publisher = | access-date = }}</ref>
Types of intellectual property typically include: * Copyright * Patents * Trademarks * [[Industrial design|Industrial designs]] * [[Geographical indication|Geographical indications]]
In today’s highly competitive [[consumer electronics]] industry, given the nature of the products and the quality of the market, Patents and Industrial designs are arguably becoming the most concerned types of intellectual property.
== The necessity of protecting intellectual property in consumer electronics industry == First, patents and industrial designs have a strong presence in the consumer electronics industry. As evidenced by the steady stream of novel high-tech offerings and the rate at which the latest gadgets become ‘‘[[Obsolescence|obsolete]],’’ companies in the electrical industry invest millions in [[research and development]] to meet the immense demand for new, useful technologies, and to help bring to market the next wave of cutting-edge products for consumers. The fruits of this research and development - which gives rise to the technologies themselves or to a key component of a particular products’ functionality - are typically protected through patents.<ref>{{Cite book | title = Intellectual Property in Consumer Electronics, Software and Technology Startups - Springer | last = Halt | first = Gerald B. | last2 = Halt | first2 = Gerald B. | last3 = Donch | first3 = John C. | last4 = Stiles | first4 = Amber R. | last5 = Fesnak | first5 = Robert | doi = 10.1007/978-1-4614-7912-3 |year = 2014|isbn = 978-1-4614-7911-6}}</ref>
Second, the consequence of leaking patents and industrial designs could be devastating. One of the examples is the series of ongoing lawsuits between [[Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co.|Apple and Samsung]] regarding the design of smartphones and tablet computers.
== Practice in developing a company’s IP protection measures == On strategic level, a common practice is to develop an effective IP protection strategy. The following steps is commonly used in establishing such strategy:<ref>{{Cite book | title = The IT Digital Legal Companion | last = Landy | first = Gene K | publisher = Elsevier Inc | year = 2008 | isbn = 978-1-59749-256-0 | location = USA | pages = 99–135 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last = Thomas | first = John | date = Jan 6, 2010 | title = Intellectual Property in Industrial Designs: Issues in Innovation and Competition | url = | journal = Congressional Research Service Report | doi = | pmid = | access-date = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last = Aggarwal | first = Raj | date = 2010-11-01 | title = Business strategies for multinational intellectual property protection | journal = Thunderbird International Business Review | language = en | volume = 52 | issue = 6 | pages = 541–551 | doi = 10.1002/tie.20378 | issn = 1520-6874 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://wipo.int/designs/en/ | title = International Designs on the WIPO web site | last = | first = | date = | website = | publisher = | access-date = Feb 28, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last = Gupta | first = Meenu | date = 2010-02-01 | title = A new strategy for the protection of intellectual property | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1361372310700099 | journal = Computer Fraud & Security | volume = 2010 | issue = 2 | pages = 8–10 | doi = 10.1016/S1361-3723(10)70009-9 }}</ref> * the first step is to identify the [[Strategic management|corporate strategy]] and determine the best means for aligning the corporate strategy with the IP strategy * in order to properly identify IP [[Asset|assets]], it is critical that a thorough IP audit be performed by personnel within the corporation who are knowledgeable or familiar with the company’s IP or the company’s technology plan. * determining whether the identified IP assets are core assets * properly allocating corporate resources to core and non-core IP assets * setting up a program for periodic review of IP assets On operational level, and given that the development phase usually involves developing various [[Prototype|prototypes]] and [[Blueprint|blueprints]] and sometimes have to work with third party vendors under circumstances, establishing a secrecy program throughout the whole project team would be beneficial in mitigating the leak risk. The following is a list of key questions need to be asked in the development phase of such secrecy program. * Identify the external and internal parties and understand the roles and responsibilities * Consider legal options on the table prior to engaging. For internal team/staff, [[Non-disclosure agreement|NDA]] is the minimum requirement. For external party, [[master service agreement]] (MSA) along with vendor obligation and [[Penalty clause|penalty clauses]] is a favorable option. * Enforcing ongoing secrecy protection program. The elements that could put into the program include the statement of security responsibilities for vendors, the right to perform IP compliance and security compliance vendor assessment at the company’s discretion. * Establishing Information security requirements. * Conduct IP protection and secrecy awareness training to all required person. * Determine leak investigation capacity
== References == {{Reflist}}
